reviewText: SPOILERS:Jonathan (James Caan) rules the sports world of the violent game Rollerball. In this world ruled by corporations, Jonathan has done something that no other player has done--dominated the sport for years and survived. The corporation head (John Houseman) wants Jonathan to retire something that he is dead set against. Rollerball has replaced war as a means for the world to work out its aggression and, like any great warrior, Jonathan loves the game so much he refuses to give it up putting him in direct conflict with the Energy Corporation that owns his team. The Corporation has other plans...eliminating rules and making the game more dangerous to force Jonathan to reconsider his decision.END OF SPOILERS:Director Norman Jewison's film manages to capture the thrill of dangerous sports while acting as a somewhat ironic commentary on our society's obsession with them. Relatively successful, many viewers missed the point of "Rollerball" when it was released precisely because of how well shot and made the film was as they got caught up in the onscreen action.The limited edition (3000 copies from Twilight Time and available here, as well as, at the website Screen Archives where it is $29.99)boasts a handsome transfer of the film. Colors are strong throughout and the natural film grain of the film is evident in this transfer. While there are a few isolated sequences where detail and sharpness fail to match the best moments here, "Rollerball" receives a pleasing presentation on blu-ray.The audio sounds quite nice as well. We get the original mono soundtrack (and it sounds very nice in its lossless presentation) in addition to a nicely produced 5.1 mix that provides some additional depth to the original soundtrack.As with all the Twilight Time releases, we get a very good boolet by Julie Kirgo where she discusses the impact of the film, critical reception and provides us with a bit of trivia.This release shines (aside from the nice HD presentation)compared to other Twilight Time releases due to the special features included on this edition and imported over from the 2002 DVD and the International release.First up we get a scene specific commentary from the late author and screenwriter William Harrison who penned both the original source story and this adaptation for film. We get a second commentary track from the late director Norman Jewison discussing the movie as well.The release also features a 2001 25 minute featurette on the making of the film with new interviews (at the time) from co-star John Beck, writer William Harrison and others discussing the making of the film, its message, impact and how both sometimes got lost in the spectacle of the film.The vintage featurette "Full Circle" is also quite interesting providing good insight into the inspiration for the film.Finally, we get trailers, TV spots and an isolated music score to round out the special features. Norman Jewison's lovely score as well as the use of classical music is a highlight of the film and the isolated track does a nice job of conveying how much his contribution is to the finished film.Although it might have been nice to get some new material on the film (particularly with the participation of Caan), what we get here is extremely good and I must give kudos to Twiight Time for trying to include the extras we get.Although overshadowed by the horrible remake from 2002 in many people's minds, "Rollerball" remains a powerful science fiction thriller with a strong idea and slick presentation. Although the message of the film sometimes gets lost and muddled, the film remains a strong example of social commentary in science fiction presented in a populist way that manages to be entertaining.Recommended.
summary: Classic science fiction film receives nice blu-ray transfer, extras from Twilight Time. This is a limited edition release.

reviewText: Being both an avid fan of violent sports and sci-fi/action flicks, 'Roller ball' was definitely a must-see for me. The so-called 'future tech' look of the movie hasn't held up all that well- like its fellow 70s sci-fi flicks 'Logan's Run' and 'Silent Running', it does have a less-than-timeless look to it. One good example is the players' skating of the old-fashioned 2-axle roller skates, rather than the in-line "blades" commonly used nowadays. Then there's a few scenes where our hard-hitting heroes are doing their between-game sojourns to the library in plain white polyester leisure/jump-suits. There's a mini-doc featuring more of the director's explanation as to what this movie's message is, and the obligatory trailer.
